11. Style of the Laelius. Previous to the last period of Cicero's literary activity there was no vocabulary in the Latin language to express the philosophical terms of the Greeks. In spite of the fact that words never failed Cicero ’ in his transfer of Greek thought to Latin idiom, he felt

shades of meaning for which no Latin word existed. ’

Accordingly he had to resort to paraphrases, circumlocu- tions, ellipses, and newly coined words. Cicero also tried to give the essay an air of reality in the mouth of Laelius by using archaic forms and expressions Attention is called to these in the explanatory notes, and also 'to the introduc· tion of certain oratorical turns showing that Cicero could not entirely conceal his own profession.
